fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

If you have the "Add repositories" permissions you get access to the "Bitbucket Server repositories" tab that let's you add repos from Bitbucket. If you begin adding repos it shows an "added" indicator in place of the button. 

The list does not indicate repositories that were added by other users. You only get a "Repository with given name already exists" message.

h3. Suggested Solution

Indicate that others have already added the repository from Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Indicate which repositories have been added from Bitbucket

fields.description:
Fisheye and Crucible did not check that the name of a file in a Mercurial repository contained argument parameters. An attacker who has permission to add a repository or commit to a mercurial repository tracked by Fisheye or Crucible, can execute code of their choice on systems that run a vulnerable version of Fisheye or Crucible.
All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.3 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.1 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 



*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.3 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.1 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 

*Fix:*
 * Fisheye version 4.5.1 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download].
 * Crucible version 4.5.1 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download].
 * Fisheye version 4.4.3 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download-archives].
 * Crucible version 4.4.3 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download-archives].


*Acknowledgements*
Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.


For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/qVcGO].
fields.summary: Argument injection in Mercurial repository handling - CVE-2017-14591
Dev Panel doesn't update with rest of ticket

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When removing repositories, a repository is not properly removed from the cross repository index. With many deleted repositories and a large cross repository index this can slow down the start of Fisheye&Crucible.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Index repositories. 

Remove repositories via one of the following:
 * user admin panel
 * REST API: DELETE /rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories/repository-name
 * manually from config.xml

Restart instance. Time required for startup increases. 

 
h3. Expected Results

Fisheye successfully cleans cross-repository index and performs it only once.

h3. Actual Results

Fisheye on every start will try to clean the cross repository index and fail silently. Startup time is much longer, which can be identified by amount of time which passes between "Starting plugin system" and "Starting mail system" log messages.

{noformat}
2017-09-23 12:56:22,020 INFO - Starting database...
2017-09-23 12:56:22,595 INFO - BoneCP - tracking statements enabled for pool [mainPool]
2017-09-23 12:56:24,510 INFO - BoneCP - tracking statements enabled for pool [retriablePool]
2017-09-23 12:56:24,947 INFO - Database started.
2017-09-23 12:56:27,396 INFO - Starting plugin system...  <<<<<
2017-09-23 13:19:26,622 INFO - Starting mail system...   <<<<<  over 20 minutes elapsed
{noformat}


h3. Workaround

Workaround for slow start: re-add repositories - just match the name, repository itself can be empty - so the Fisheye & Crucible does not try to remove those repositories from the index on start.

In order to identify for which deleted repositories Fisheye tries to clean up cross-repository index, [configure Byteman logging|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/enable-byteman-for-additional-logging-in-fisheye-and-crucible-943956769.html] and load the following rules: [^logging.btm]. Look for a message like:

{noformat}
-- CrossRepLuceneIndex#purgeOldReps List repos to remove <list>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Cleaning cross repository index on start from removed repositories fails

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: 
 * add N repositories
 * remove those N repositories (via UI, REST, manually from config.xml - it doesn't matter)
 * restart Fisheye&Crucible and see it tries to clean the cross repository, in the logs all looks fine
 * restart Fisheye&Crucible again and see it tries again to remove those repositories from the cross repository index
fields.summary: Cleaning cross repository index on start from incorrectly removed repositories fails

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Indexing fails on a SVN repository which has a large binary file.

h3. Environment

* Use *SVNKit* for the subversion client

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Add SVN repository to FishEye
#- Use {{file://}} protocol to access the repository
# Commit a large binary file to the repository
# Start full indexing on the repository

h3. Expected Results

Indexing should be completed as expected.

h3. Actual Results

Indexing failed with the following exception.

{code:java}
2017-11-02 00:15:05,093 INFO  [IncrPing1 test_svn ] fisheye RepositoryEngine-startPause - Repository scanner paused. Error: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Can't overwrite cause with org.tmatesoft.svn.core.SVNException: svn: E160004: Can't read length line from file /home/svn/test/db/revs/0/1: Input length = 1
{code}
 
h3. Notes

* Set Include/Exclude Paths on the problematic large binary file couldn't be the workaround for this problem
* The problem didn't occurred in case that {{http://}} protocol was used to access the repository
* The problem didn't occurred in case that native SVN is used for the subversion client

h3.Workaround

# Use {{http://}} protocol instead
# Use native SVN instead
fields.summary: Indexing fails on a SVN repository which has a large binary file

fields.description: Currently the default settings on a fresh FishEye installation defaults to global allow visibility for the repositories. This makes it so if the installer does not change the authentication settings, any added repositories are visible to whoever has access to the server. This should be set to default deny and only allowed should the admin wish.
fields.summary: Default settings for new installations should be default deny for global access, not default allow

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently users might count towards the license indefinitely, even after months of inactivity, until they get deleted from the instance. For large companies, controlling who should still have access to the instance might be a challenge.

h3. Suggested Solution
There should be a way of inactivating users who do not logged into Fisheye application for more than a configurable number of days or months automatically.
fields.summary: Inactivate users after configurable number of inactivity days

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The Fisheye Crucible administrator expects the database migration should have thrown an error stating that the database in SQL Server did not exist in the first place to perform migration instead of throwing an error related to executing the script *drop_105.sql* and request to run the *drop_105.sql* manually as the migration tool in the instance UI unable to do so.

h3. Expected Result
The *Migration Database* page shows that the database does not exist in the database server before kick off with the migration.

h3. Actual Result
Once the backup is completed, at migration process the error mention performing manual work on running the *drop_105.sql* script since the migration tool unable to execute the script such: !Migration Fail.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: More clear message when target database does not exist when using Database Migration

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently Global Permissions are only inherited by users from their immediate groups.  Users in groups that are nested within other groups do not inherit permissions from the parent group.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow users in nested groups to inherit permissions from parent groups.

h3. Why this is important
Simplifies permission configuration, reducing the number of configuration changes needed to assign permissions to multiple nested groups
 
h3. Workaround 
Manually assign permissions for each nested group.
fields.summary: Global Permissions set for parent LDAP groups should be inherited by nested LDAP groups

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The Fisheye backup (using the {{$ ./fisheyectl.sh backup}} script) is created with the read/write permissions for the Fisheye users:
{noformat}
-rw-------
{noformat}

This is also the case when the script is run by a different user.

When setting up an automatic process for creating the backups and moving them to a different location after the backup is not complete will require extra steps.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow the backup file to be created with different permissions.
fields.summary: As an administrator, I would like to specify the permissions of the backup files

fields.description:
When connecting to SQL Server and you use the wrong character encoding you get the error message:
{quote}The database is not using Unicode. FishEye and Crucible Require that the database uses a UTF8 encoding to support internalization.
{quote}
This should be update that to {{Latin1_General_CS_AS}} for SQL server per [migrating to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/migrating-to-sql-server-298976839.html].
fields.summary: Update error when connecting with SQL Server

E.g.

a34 1

fields.description:
Some response codes that is returned by FishEye may appear to be a valid request but due to the state, the response may have been generalised to code 400. However, it doesn't apply to some of the endpoints in which this promotes inconsistency. As an example:

 
 * While using /*rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories* endpoint to add repository that have already existed returns a code response 400
 * While using */rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories/\{repository}/start* to start a repository that already started also returns a code response 400
 * However, while using */rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories/\{repository}/permissions/groups* to add permission when the group have already been added will return a code response 304

 
 From the official [W3 Status Code Definition|https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html], the first two REST API should not have returned 400 as the request seems to be still valid without syntax error but may not be represented the same in FishEye under the hood.
fields.summary: Improve on response code for REST API requests

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Perforce repository indexing fails when the file path (including the filename) contains a non Unicode character.
h3. Environment
 * Perforce is configured as non Unicode

h3. Steps to Reproduce

N/A
h3. Expected Results

The indexing works and the files are available in FishEye
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-MM-DD.log}} file:
{noformat}
WARN - Problem processing revisions from repository <repository_name> due to class com.cenqua.fisheye.perforce.client.P4ClientException - Unable to get file log for <file path/filename>
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

The following alternative options are available as a workaround:
 # *(Preferred)* Convert the repository to a Unicode one in Perforce.
 # Add the {{fisheye.ignore.p4.client.errors=true}} property to the {{JVM system properties}} (see [JVM system properties - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-298976942.html] and [Environment variable|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/environment-variables-298976934.html]). This can be achieved in the following way:
 ## add the following to the {{$FISHEYE_INST/system.properties}} file
{noformat}
fisheye.ignore.p4.client.errors=true
{noformat}
 ## add the following to the {{FISHEYE_OPTS}} environment variable
{noformat}
-Dfisheye.ignore.p4.client.errors=true
{noformat}

h3. Solution

Fisheye allows you to define encoding for Perforce repository.
Before Fisheye 4.6.1 this encoding was used only to process Perforce output. In Fisheye 4.6.1 and later, also input commands are constructed with encoding that is readable by Perforce.

To make sure that the Fisheye input is readable for the Perforce repository,
repository encoding has to be set according to the file paths encoding in the repository.

For example, if a committer uses Windows machine with windows-1252 (“Western Europe") character set as their default encoding, the same encoding must be set in Fisheye.
fields.summary: Indexing a Perforce repository fails with "P4ClientException - Unable to get file log" for files with non Unicode characters

fields.description:
h3. Summary

{{sun.jnu.encoding}} is not explicitly defined in the startup of the FishEye JVM, and so it's possible for this to be set to an unexpected value in a customer's environment which causes issues with extended UTF-8 characters, e.g. working with Chinese text in a file

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have your environment set up with {{sun.jnu.encoding}} as {{GBK}} by default
# Create a file containing special characters


h3. Expected Results
Even if your JVM is configured like that by default, FishEye server should force it to be {{UTF-8}}.

h3. Actual Results
Chinese text does not appear correctly in FishEye/Crucible.

h3. Workaround

Set {{sun.jnu.encoding}} explicitly to {{UTF-8}} in the *{{$FISHEYE_OPTS}}* [Environment variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/environment-variables-298976934.html]:

{code}
-Dsun.jnu.encoding=UTF-8
{code}
fields.summary: Set sun.jnu.encoding to UTF-8 by default

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the Charts are displayed with no identifying information, just numbers and dates.  There is no definition for what the numbers mean.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add axis titles

h3. Why this is important
As the Chart is displayed, it displays data with no meaning therefore is not helpful.
fields.summary: Add axis titles to the Chart reports

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Selecting users and/or file extensions using the current select boxes when using *Charts* is time consuming if you have a lot of options and you only want a subset spread across the list. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a text box that allows you to type the user name or extension (depending on the selection box)

h3. Why this is important
Simplifies the process for creating Chart reports.
fields.summary: As a user I would like to be able to select users and file extensions in the Charts using a text box

h3. Workaround

Create a {{$FISHEYE_INST\content}} directory, which can be empty but must exist.

*Note: * This only affects windows versions.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When deleting multiple repositories in a short time frame, the "A repository with the name <repository name> does not exist" is presented in the user interface.
These messages are harmless and are not representing any real issue, they are only temporary and will be resolved by a refresh.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
+Note+: we have not been able to reproduce this in our labs, but it appears to happen when deleting a sequence of repositories in a short time frame.
The total number of repositories may also be a significant factor.

h3. Expected Results
No error messages are shown in the user interface.

h3. Actual Results
The following message is shown as an error in the user interface:
{noformat}
"A repository with the name <repository name> does not exist"
{noformat}


The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-fisheye-yyyy-mm-dd.log}} file:
{noformat}
WARN [<thread_id>] / ContextHandler$Context-log - Exception while dispatching incoming RPC call
com.google.gwt.user.server.rpc.UnexpectedException: Service method 'public abstract com.atlassian.fecru.gwt.admin.shared.repositories.RepositoryOperationalSummary com.atlassian.fecru.gwt.admin.client.RepositoryAdminRpcService.getRepositoryOperationalSummary(java.lang.String) throws com.atlassian.fecru.gwt.admin.shared.AuthorizationException,com.atlassian.fecru.gwt.admin.shared.OperationFailureException,com.atlassian.fecru.gwt.admin.shared.NoSuchRepositoryException' threw an unexpected exception: org.apache.xmlbeans.impl.values.XmlValueDisconnectedException
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Not available.
fields.summary: Removing a sequence of repositories may lead to "A repository with the name <repository name> does not exist"

fields.description:
h3. Summary

User Directories shows operation history without considering timezone which is configured at server settings
h3. Environment
 * FishEye 4.2.1
 * JIRA 7.3.3

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open !https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/files/776636099/779167496/1/1441849917468/cog.png! > _Server Settings_ > _Edit settings_
 # Change timezone to other than system timezone such as from _"UTC"_ to _"Japan"_
 # Restart FishEye to apply settings
 # Open !https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/files/776636099/779167496/1/1441849917468/cog.png! > _User Directories_ > _Add Directory_ > Select _"Atlassian JIRA"_ > _Next_
 # Connect to [JIRA Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye042/connecting-to-jira-for-user-management-869175047.html]
 # Confirm _"Last synchronised at"_ doesn't respect configured timezone
 **  !Screenshot_2017-07-05_14_09_42.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
 * _"Last synchronised at"_ takes account of configured timezone
 * Or, append timezone notation to _"Last synchronised at"_

h3. Actual Results

_"Last synchronised at"_ shows time with system timezone (possibly hardcoded in _UTC_)

h3. Notes
 * None

h3. Workaround
 * None
fields.summary: "Last synchronised" doesn't respect configured timezone

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

*Simplified scenario:*
-- on branch A, perform a change, add it and commit it (*don't push it*)
-- on branch B, perform a change, add it, commit it and *push it*
--- FishEye will index this chance and the email for this change will be sent
-- *push* the change performed on branch A
--- FishEye will index this chance but the email for this change will *not* be sent

*Real world scenario:*
Supposing that user A commits something locally into a branch A, then other people commit and push to the repo in branch B, then that user A pushes his commits later on.

This is currently how it works because, even though the commit performed by user A was made before the commits from other people, the changeset was pushed by user A *after* these people pushed theirs, so the changeset pushed by user A is now *older* then the ones already pushed by other people, and these *newer* changesets from other people have been successfully processed by FishEye and had email notifications sent. However, FishEye will not process email notifications for older changesets, which is the situation of the changeset pushed by user A later on.

The logic below (found in the source code) only triggers the email to be sent if the change has been performed after the {{lastChecked}} value:
{code}
private List<ChangeSet> checkWatch(FecruUser user, Watch watch, RepositoryEngine rep, Principal principal) throws DbException {
...
long lastChecked = watch.getLastChecked();
...
if (revLastMod > lastChecked) {
...
watch.setLastChecked(revLastMod);
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
As FishEye recognizes these pushes containing older changesets and indexes them just fine, why not send notifications as well?

h3. Workaround
There are no known workarounds yet.
fields.summary: Send notifications for older changesets pushed after newer changesets get pushed

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The "View as Patch" feature may take a long time causing the entire application to respond slowly to the users' requests.



h3. Steps to Reproduce
Not available

h3. Expected Results
The performances of the application are not affected by a particularly slow request.

h3. Actual Results
The below timing can be observed in the {{atlassian-fisheye.log}} file:
{noformat}
DEBUG [qtp<thread_id> ] fisheye ProfilingServletFilter-logRequest - end request in 41553473ms GET /rdiff/<repository_name>?csid=72665&u=&N= nosession 200 mem=1134510.476MB
{noformat}

Alternative options to address this issue could be:
- allow disabling entirely the request/feature
- improve the overall performances of the request

h3.Workaround
- If the requests are not performed by a user (e.g. a Web Crawler may be requesting such links), they can be blocked at a proxy level
fields.summary: The "View as Patch" request may take a long time causing the application to respond slowly
New FAQ item explaining what happens when the number of users exceeds the license count

fields.description: I often get page after page of deleted files in my quick search results.  This makes it really hard for me to find things. Quick search should excluded deleted files by default, with an option to show deleted files as well.
fields.summary: Exclude deleted files from quick search results by default

fields.description: fisheye log scanner regex fisheye_regex_v2.xml only flags one instance of a malloc failure ("There is insufficient memory for the Java Runtime Environment to continue"), but there are additional malloc errors that can indicate high priority problems with fisheye.  Or perhaps more importantly, errors from forking git which lead to a corrupted local copy of a remote repository.  A corrupted local copy can cause many downstream issues, so I believe the phrase "Out of memory, malloc failed" as in the attached file should also flag a high priority issue.
fields.summary: log scanner should flag additional malloc errors

fields.description:
Currently, the closest REST endpoint to retrieve details about a repository permission only includes if the repository is either:
* Using the default permissions
* Is granted for anonymous users
* Is granted for all logged in users

However, it doesn't mention the list of users/group that have access to the repository.
fields.summary: Getting a list of users with repository permissions via REST

fields.description:
Previously, any email notification received by an end user, the title of the email describes what action had been performed. As an example:

[Crucible] 1 comment added: (TEST-203) 
[Crucible] Finished reviewing: (TEST-227)

Now, the title of the email is generic such as :

[FishEye and Crucible] TEST-01: some description of the commit... 
[FishEye and Crucible] TEST-02: some description of the commit ...
fields.summary: Notification title should re-include the action item instead of a generic statement

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

FishEye does not support creation of groups with a slash ({{/}}) in the name:
 !Screen Shot 2017-05-05 at 15.01.25.png!
h3. Suggested Solution

Permit FishEye to handle groups with slashes in the name.
h3. Why this is important

Crowd and JIRA support group names with a slash ({{/}}) in the name and, if used as external directory for FishEye the groups get synced to FishEye overcoming the limitations that is in place only during the group creation.
 !Screen Shot 2017-06-09 at 11.33.44.png!

Still once the group is synced into FishEye is not possible to assign any permission to it.
h3. Workaround
 * Rename groups to remove the slash ({{/}})
 * Use backslash ( \ ) in group names in case you need it as a logical separator
fields.summary: As an administrator I would like to have support for slash ( / ) in group names

fields.description:
h3. Not a bug
(i) This is not a bug, instead this occured when a Microsoft JDBC driver was in use instead of the jtds one.

We have seen this message being logged when taking a backup of Fisheye or migrating to a new database.

Note that only the bundled driver is supported as described on the [Migrating to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/migrating-to-sql-server-298976839.html] page: 
{quote}
The JDBC jtds drivers for SQLServer are bundled with FishEye/Crucible. We do not support using the Microsoft distributed jdbc driver.
{quote}

The {{config.xml}} file contains the following:
{code:xml}
<database type="sqlserver2012">
    <connection  dialect="com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.dialects.SQLServer2008UnicodeDialect" 
            driver="com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver"
            jdbcurl="jdbc:sqlserver://(database):(port);databaseName=crucible"
            password="(password)"
            username="(username)"
            maxPoolSize="20" minPoolSize="5" driverSource="bundled"/>
{code}


In the {{jdbcurl}} attribute we would expect *jdbc:jtds:sqlserver* instead of *jdbc:sqlserver*, also the {{driver}} attribute should be *net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbc.Driver* instead of *com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver*.

In the application.xml from a Support Zip, you'll be able to see see that the database is configured in this way:
{code:xml}
<database-information>
    <database-name>SQLServer 2012 or newer</database-name>
    <driver-name>net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbc.Driver</driver-name>
    <connection-url>jdbc:sqlserver://(database):(port);databaseName=crucible</connection-url>
    <database-version>101</database-version>
{code}

The driver name looks fine but the protocol does not match what we would expect.


h3. Resolution
To update the current configuration, follow these steps:
# Stop Fisheye
# Locate the the {{$FISHEYE_INST/config.xml}} file
# Update the database connection details by replacing the current details with the required ones:
## {{net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbc.Drive}} as driver
## {{jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://<database>:<port>;databaseName=<databaseName>}} (make sure to use the existing database url, port and name
# Start Fisheye

h3. Summary - original description

Creating a backup of FishEye or migrating to a new Database fails with:
{code}
Error reading database: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: nvarchar

2017-06-05 01:18:49,948 WARN  [ThreadPool1 ] fisheye BackupManagerImpl$2-run - Backup failed.
java.io.IOException: Error reading database: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: "nvarchar" (-9) of column .membership_type
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.SQLBackup$SaverImpl.backup(SQLBackup.java:81) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.BackupManagerImpl.createBackup(BackupManagerImpl.java:264) [fisheye.jar:?]
....
Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: "nvarchar" (-9) of column .membership_type
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.DBExporter.throwCantEncodeJdbcType(DBExporter.java:351) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.DBExporter.access$400(DBExporter.java:35) [fisheye.jar:?]
{code} 

h3. Environment
* FishEye migrated to SQL Server

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Unable to reproduce locally

h3. Expected Results
- The backup or migration completes successfully 

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-fisheye-XXXX-XX-XX.log file:
{noformat}
Error reading database: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: nvarchar
{noformat}
fields.summary: Backup of SQL Server 2014 SP1 fails due to unsupported column type "nvarchar" (-9)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
There's a variety of settings in _"SCM details"_ as described at [Configuring repository details|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-repository-details-298976916.html], however FishEye only offers 1 default for _"SCM details"_ in Repository Settings > Defaults > SCM Details.

 !Screenshot_2017-05-30_15_06_01.png|thumbnail! 

This severity will be more serious for example especially for customers handling large size of SVM repositories because FishEye only offers hard-coded default for [SVN Operation Timeout|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/subversion-298976887.html] (currently 4 hours as [FE-5015|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-5015]). Otherwise admin users need to set up each repository settings every time adding repository.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add feature to set up default options (e.g. timeout) for each SCMs.

h3. Workaround
None.
fields.summary: Add more options in Repository Settings > Defaults > SCM Details

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When deleting a repository, all the web hooks configured for all repositories are deleted.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a web hook, choosing "All" in "Repository" field
# Delete any repository from FishEye

h3. Expected Results
Only the web hooks for the deleted repository are removed.

h3. Actual Results
All web hooks for the deleted repository are removed, but also +all web hooks set for "All" repositories are removed+.
Web hooks set specifically for other repositories are not removed.

No errors are reported in the logs.
Debug logs don't contain any related information.

h3.Workaround
- *Workaround 1*: Re-add all cross-repository web hooks after removing a repository.
- *Workaround 2*: Use per-repository web hooks only.
- *Workaround 3*: Don't remove repositories, disable them instead (disk space will not be released, though).
fields.summary: Cross-repository web hooks are removed when any repository is deleted

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The [Environment variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/environment-variables-298976934.html] page mentions the {{-XX:MaxPermSize=128m}} Java setting.

This value is deprecated since Java 1.8, which is the only Java version supported by FishEye, and should be removed.

The following page:
- http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/tools/unix/java.html

Mentions:
{quote}
*-XX:MaxPermSize=size*
Sets the maximum permanent generation space size (in bytes). This option was deprecated in JDK 8, and superseded by the -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize option.
{quote}
fields.summary: Remove the mention to "XX:MaxPermSize" from the "Environment variables" page

fields.description:
I'm using FishEye to index Git repositories on a [Gerrit server|https://www.gerritcodereview.com/]. I noticed that while indexing the repositories FishEye takes a lot of time. Investigating further I noticed that when I "start" the repository FishEye uses the following command to fetch it:
{noformat}
/usr/bin/git fetch https://user:XXXX@gerrit.example.com/code +refs/\*:refs/\*
{noformat}
The problem seems to be the refspec used to fetch ({{+refs/\*:refs/\*}}). As you may know, Gerrit uses special references under {{refs/changes}} to keep the history of commit revisions. When FishEye fetches the repository it brings all this history which is irrelevant for the purposes we want to use FishEye to. One of our repositories has ~11.000 references under {{refs/changes}}.

I opened a support issue and was told that currently there is no way to specify a different refspec. *So, I'm asking for an new feature to be implemented so that when I configure a Git repository in FishEye I can specify the refspec that it will use to fetch from the repository.*

I'd also like to argue that the default refspec should be different. I think it should be {{+refs/heads/\*:refs/heads/\*}} and {{+refs/tags/\*:refs/tags/\*}} so that by default FishEye would index only the repository's branches and tags.

As it currently is ({{+refs/\*:refs/\*}}) FishEye brings from the remote Git repository things we usually wouldn't be interested in. In the case of Gerrit, it brings all the review history under {{refs/changes}}, which is irrelevant. There are other tools which use other reference namespaces for bookkeeping and that would potentially cause problems too. For instance, the [SubGit|https://subgit.com/] convertion tool which keeps under {{refs/svn}} several bookkeeping references. Another one is the command {{git-filter-branch}} which keeps references under {{refs/original}}. If I use any of these tools I will "polute" the reference namespace and FishEye will try to bring them all and index them with no purpose.

Thank you for your attention!
fields.summary: Add option to specify the refspec used to fetch a Git repository

fields.description:
Large SVN repositories with a number of branches and long history can be too large for Fisheye to successfully index.  Although include paths are helpful, they aren't used when Fisheye collects SVN properties for the initial revision specified.  This slows down the initial indexing and re-indexing since there is a single `svn proplist` at the much larger repository level.

Performance in this scenario could be improved by performing separate `svn proplist` calls for each include path for the Fisheye repository.  This approach would allow admins to configure the repository for the granularity necessary to meet performance needs.
fields.summary: Break up `svn proplist` call on re-indexing

Click on the "Delta lines of code" link on reports header bar, to remove branch/tag selection from the URL.
fields.summary: DLOC Report reports errors in log when branch or tag parameter provided

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

PDF product documentation for FishEye, Crucible, and Confluence are hosted in the Atlassian Cloud (Bitbucket.org) and redirected to Amazon AWS while the other product documentation is hosted directly on Atlassian.com.

If this is not known, we are unable to retrieve the PDF downloads on a restricted network.

h3. Suggested Solution

Please include a note or reference for those on restricted networks that the PDF documentation resides elsewhere to open up network access.
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/alldoc/applications-and-tools-documentation-directory-209586313.html
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/atlassian-cloud-ip-ranges-and-domains-744721662.html
fields.summary: Update documentation to include reference PDF download location

fields.description:
h4. Problem Definition

When Synchronizing groups from LDAP, the group attribute, description, is not displayed in the UI and there is no option to display it. The description is stored in the database table {{cwd_group}}.

h4. Suggested Solution

Display group Description in UI when listing Groups.

h4. Workaround

No workaround at the moment.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like to be able to see the group description in the UI

fields.description: When the path to a file is exceeds the size of the *Recent Activity* box on the *Dashboard*, FishEye/Crucible does not wrap the text or provide a scrollbar.  The especially sensitive in SVN repositories.  Screenshot attached.
fields.summary: Recent Activity on the Dashboard does not wrap very long paths

fields.description:
The [Custom authentication|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/custom-authentication-813695575.html] page, in "Per-repository constraint configuration" section, has this link in "Permissions Summary table": http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/6.+Setting+up+your+Users+and+Security. 

Clicking it takes you to a "Page Not Found", and the links from "In Other Spaces" are really outdated. Clicking in the most recent link listed there, for FishEye 1.6, takes you to: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE016/6.+Setting+up+your+Users+and+Security. 

However, removing the initial "6.+" from the page link (so that it looks like https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE016/Setting+up+your+Users+and+Security), takes you to another "Page Not Found", and then the links from "In Other Spaces" show that the latest version available for that document is for FishEye 2.7: 
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE027/Setting+up+your+Users+and+Security

This link for FishEye 2.7 really seems to be the latest one, however it's obviously really outdated as well, as FishEye's current latest version is 4.4.0.
fields.summary: Custom Authentication page links to outdated documentation

fields.description:
*Problem:*

In order to map existing users to committers FishEye has to scan through cached repository data. In case of large repositories with long commit history, it may take much time.

 

*Workaround:*

The dark feature implemented allows to disable search through repository data. User can still have a mapping by defining it explicitly:
 * via Administration > User Mappings 
 * or via user avatar > Profile

 

*How to enable it:*

Go to: [http://your_instance/plugins/servlet/global-dark-features]
 Enter: *atlassian.darkfeature.disable.implicit.committers* to the Feature Key textbox and click Enable.

 

*The dark feature is available in:*
 * 4.0.3-ea29981 (a dev build)
 * 4.4.1 (planned)
 * 4.5.0 (planned)
fields.summary: A dark feature flag to disable implicit committers

fields.description: After defining a user with Global Permission, we can see that the user is counted towards the license limit. However, removing the user (retaining it on Global Permission) does not reduce the license limit. The workaround is to remove that user as well from Global Permission.
fields.summary: Deleting a user in FishEye/Crucible does not reduce the license limit

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Any user starting with any of the letters present in the first 25 user entries (user name, display name or email address) will not be searchable using user auto-complete in the User Selector

h3. Environment

Any compatible browser is affected.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 25 accounts named:
{noformat}
username: a1, Display-name: A1, email: a1@abc.example.com
...
username: a25, Display-name: A25, email: a25@abc.example.com
{noformat}

 # Create 1 additional account:
{noformat}
username: b1, Display-name: B1, email: b1@abc.example.com
{noformat}

 # Create a review
 # Try to mention user b1 in a comment

h3. Expected Results

User b1 gets showed in the selector.
h3. Actual Results

No user is found:
 !Screen Shot 2017-03-31 at 12.07.38.png|thumbnail!

It does not work either with full mention:
 !Screen Shot 2017-03-31 at 12.12.59.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround 1
 # Create 1 additional account:
{noformat}
username: z1, Display-name: ZB, email: z1@abc.example.com
{noformat}

 # Search for z1, it gets listed
 !Screen Shot 2017-03-31 at 12.16.14.png|thumbnail!
 # Now exact mention works for b1:
 !Screen Shot 2017-03-31 at 12.16.43.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround 2
Avoid user selector by directly typing markup for user mention. E.g. for user "{{b}}" type "{{\[\~b\]}}".
fields.summary: User Selector does not find user if more than 25 users contain the username starting letter in username or email address.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In instances having thousands of groups, configuring Global Permissions is painful because the user needs to type the group names one by one in the "Pick one or more groups" field.
 Some customers have also reported that the instance 'crashes' when lots of groups (for example, 50+) are added to the "Pick one or more groups" field, so they need to add groups in smaller batches.
h3. Suggested Solution

The Global Permissions page, when configuring groups, should either:
 # Present an option that allows granting the permission levels selected to all groups at once.
 *OR*
 # List all groups with a checkbox next to each of them, in order to allow selecting which ones to grant the permission levels selected.

h3. Workaround

1) Use REST api to manage global permissions for users and groups, see

[Fisheye 4.7 release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-4-7-release-notes-966664748.html] and [REST API documentation|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/4.7.0/wadl/fecru.html].

or

2)Create one group per global permission type ({{fisheye-users}}, {{crucible-users}}, {{can-add-repository}}), grant global permissions to these groups and add all users to these groups.
fields.summary: Global Permissions: Configuring thousands of groups is painful

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As described in [FishEye reports|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-reports-298976800.html], FishEye currently supports report function based on lines of code but doesn't support the one based on *numbers of changed files*.
h3. Suggested Solution

It would be nice if FishEye support report function based on *numbers of changed files*.
 The customer assumed a chart like...
 * X-Axis : Time (Day, Week, Month)
 * Y-Axis : Number of files that were modified in a given period (In case the files are changed multiple times in the period, it should be counted once)

h3. Possible workaround

We can get the similar information with using [EyeQL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/eyeql-reference-guide-298976796.html] and download it as a CSV.
h5. EyeQL query

To get the number of files that were changed (added, modified and deleted) on each day, use the following EyeQL query
{noformat}
select revisions
from dir "/"
where date >= 2016-01-01 and date < 2017-01-01
order by date
group by month
return count(distinct path), month{noformat}
adjusting the {{dir}} and {{date}} parameters according to needs. To get a per day report, change "month" to "day" in the query.

 h5. Example results

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Create report based on numbers of changed files

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After a connection reset in the logs, the application does not restablish the connection automatically leading to failing operations when attempting to create a new connection.

h3. Environment
* SQLServer (this has been observed when running SQLServer, however other databases may be affected)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# N/A

h3. Expected Results
Even after a connection reset, FishEye is able to succesfully create new connections.

h3. Actual Results
After a connection resets in the logs:
{noformat}
ERROR [notificationManager1 ] com.jolbox.bonecp.ConnectionHandle ConnectionHandle-markPossiblyBroken - Database access problem. Killing off all remaining connections in the connection pool. SQL State = 08S01
ERROR [qtp965526499-17689 ] fisheye BoneCPConnectionHook-onCheckIn - Failed to clean up connection after use
java.sql.SQLException: I/O Error: Connection reset
{noformat}

FishEye throws {{Cannot open connection}} errors when attempting to obtain a new connection from the connection pool:
{noformat}
WARN  [notificationManager1 ] org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter JDBCExceptionReporter-logExceptions - SQL Error: 0, SQLState: HY010
ERROR [notificationManager1 ] org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter JDBCExceptionReporter-logExceptions - Invalid state, the Connection object is closed.
ERROR [notificationManager1 ] fisheye DefaultNotificationManager-processNotifications - Error while processing notifications: 
org.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
A restart of FishEye will resolve this issue.
fields.summary: Database connection does not recover by itself after a Connection reset error

fields.description:
We observed behaviour where full synchronisation with Crowd is taking 20..70 times more time to complete than JIRA or Confluence products.  Seems like this is something that could be tuned on FishEye/Crucible side.

Note: FishEye/Crucible (4.3.1) is also using older Embedded Crowd version (2.9.5) than JIRA/Confluence, there were some performance improvements introduced in 2.10 and 2.11 so upgrading Embedded Crowd may also improve this problem.
fields.summary: Full synchronisation in FECru may take order of magnitude longer than JIRA or Confluence

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
 * use FishEye or Crucible 4.3.0 or later
 * in the installer wizard paste the Atlassian Stack license key
 * FishEye installer rejects the key with a message "You've entered a Crucible license"
 * Crucible installer rejects the key with a message "You've entered a FishEye license"

 

*Workaround:*
 * in the installer wizard use an evaluation key
 * after FishEye or Crucible is installed, navigate to Administration > System Settings > System Info > License > Edit license
 * paste the same Atlassian Stack license key into "FishEye" and "Crucible" input fields
fields.summary: FishEye setup page does not accept the Atlassian Stack license key

fields.description: The ability to save a custom review filter would save a lot of time. For example, when reviews are created but a user has not yet joined as a reviewer, the only way to view that review is via a custom filter that selects our specific project and the status of Open or Under Review. Selecting a different filter such as Inbox clears the custom filter and it must be set up again. The ability to save a custom filter alongside the preexisting Outbox, Inbox, etc. filters would save a lot of headache.
fields.summary: Save Custom Filter

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Log Analyzer fails to run when reverse proxy is configured
h3. Environment

FishEye/Crucible 4.2.1+ with a Reverse Proxy Configured with:
 {{Administration > Server > Web Server}} the following:
 * Proxy Scheme
 * Proxy Port
 * Proxy Host

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up Reverse Proxy
 # Configure {{Administration > Server > Web Server}} :

 * Proxy Scheme
 * Proxy Port
 * Proxy Host

 # Run Log Analyzer using any of the 3 settings in the dropdown menu

h3. Expected Results

The logs should get scanned
h3. Actual Results

The logs don't get scanned and you automatically get the following message:
Hercules didn't find any known problems in the following log file: 
<path to file>
This happens without scanning the logs

!Screen Shot 2017-02-28 at 18.32.12.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

*Option 1*
# If FishEye is running Java 8u111+
# Add the following to the FISHEYE_OPTS:
{noformat}
-Djdk.http.auth.tunneling.disabledSchemes="" 
{noformat}

Note: see related [Basic authentication fails for outgoing proxy in Java 8u111|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/Basic+authentication+fails+for+outgoing+proxy+in+Java+8u111] article

If this workaround does not help, see FE-6966.

*Option 2*
You can set up another instance of Fisheye/Crucible 
that does not have a proxy and point the Log Analyzer 
to your proxied instance.
fields.summary: Log Analyzer fails to run when reverse proxy is configured

fields.description:
At the moment enabling debug logging in Fisheye/Crucible does not enable logging for SQL queries. 

Though there is a [manual workaround|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/enabling-additional-logging-in-fisheye-crucible-740000165.html] to add the logger to {{log4j.xml}}, it would be great to have these added to the default debug logging or enable them via the application UI, whether by the click of a button or better still similar to [JIRA's implementation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/how-to-set-logging-level-for-a-package-in-jira-629178605.html].

This will result in better user experience and help avoid issues raised as a result of errors introduced due to manual editing of files.
fields.summary: Enable SQL logging via application UI

As in a feature request [Support for IPv6|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-5702], we don't support IPv6 on FishEye at this moment.
 In [some knowledgebase|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/jira-users-can-t-login-to-fisheye-crucible-or-connecting-to-jira-for-user-management-fails-433391993.html], there seems to be some mentions about it. However, there isn't in our official docs.

We should announce it on our official docs like [Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html] as well.

{noformat}
$ p4 print //depot/10lines.txt@1 | cat -e
//depot/10lines.txt#1 - add change 1 (xtext)$
line 1$
line 2$
line 3$
line 4$
line 5$
line 6$
line 7$
line 8$
line 9$

{noformat}
$ p4 print //depot/10lines.txt@2 | cat -e
//depot/10lines.txt#2 - edit change 2 (xtext)$

line 2$

after line 3^Mcomes a line^Mwith some CR signs$

line 7$

        at com.cenqua.fisheye.util.NamedExecution.run(NamedExecution.java:27) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.PingRequest.process(PingRequest.java:52) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.processPingRequests(RepositoryHandle.java:211) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142) [?:1.8.0_60]
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617) [?:1.8.0_60]
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) [?:1.8.0_60]
{noformat}
As part of this fix, an extra log message was added to tell which line caused the problem:
{noformat}
2017-07-13 12:37:45,283 ERROR [184:StdOutHandler mixed_eol ] fisheye P4OutputLineProcessor-processOutput - Exception while processing P4 output, line 19: after line 6 comes a normal line{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Set a start revision that is higher than the changeset which cannot be indexed.
h3. Fix

(!) *This fix may not work on Windows.*

This problem is caused by FishEye wrongly splitting P4 output on any of {{LF}}, {{CR}} and {{CRLF}}, while in fact it should only split the output on the line separator specific to the environment it's running in.

The fix changes the previous behaviour and to avoid any unpleasant surprises, it will be initially hidden behing a feature flag. To use the new functionality:
 # use FishEye version at least as new as the one described in "Fix Version" field
 # start FishEye with the following [JVM system property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-298976942.html]:
{noformat}
fisheye.p4.use.system.line.separator=true{noformat}

 # re-index the repository (to save time, you can first try configuring this repository under a temporary name and setting "Start Revision" to the value printed in the log)

h3. Summary

FishEye/Crucible fails to index a Git repository on Windows if that repository contains a file of name with both a space and certain UTF-8 characters. 

h3. Environment
* Windows
* Git 2.11.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add the repository at https://bitbucket.org/atlassian-jeff/doc_test to FishEye running Windows
# Allow the repository to index

h3. Expected Results

Indexing completes without error.

h3. Actual Results

h3.Workaround

Follow the instructions on https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/fisheye-fails-to-index-a-repository-and-throws-unsupported-filetype-unable-to-read-files-to-diff-858758674.html

FishEye is passing in quotes to the {{astextplain}} script which results in the file extension not being matched. For example, the file extension is being passed in as {{.docx"}} which does not match {{.docx}}. Modifying {{astextplain}} can workaround this, simply add {{| .docx\"}} to the list:

{code}*.docx | *.DOCX | *.docm | *.DOCM | *.dotm | *.DOTM| .docx\"){code}

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When days are specified in smart commits through the usage of 'd' time unit character, such as in the example below, no time gets logged:
{noformat}
TST-1: Testing smart commits #time 1d
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate FishEye 4.2.1 with JIRA (tested with JIRA 6.4.14 and JIRA 7.2.6) through Application Links
# Ensure that OAuth consumer token has been accepted in both sides, allowing you to see JIRA issue details in FishEye side and commits / reviews in the JIRA issue
# (Likely optional) Create a user mapping, just to make sure that the repository committer will be mapped to a FishEye user
# Enable debug logging in FishEye
# Commit code using smart commits, and containing {{#time 1d}} in the commit message
# Wait until FishEye the new commit shows up in the repository activity stream
# Reload the JIRA ticket, ensuring to be in the {{Work Log}} tab, and check that the time was not logged.

h3. Expected Results
According to [Using Smart Commits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-smart-commits-298976812.html] it should be possible to use the time unit 'd', respective to days, and it should log the number of days specified before the 'd' character in the issue.

    FishEye could not execute the smart commit because of an unexpected error: Time spent '1d' must be not null and greater then zero
    Please manually perform the required action within Crucible.
{noformat}

As a result of this error, no time gets logged in the JIRA issue. 

h3.Workaround
In JIRA, 1 day of work has 8 hours, so specifying the number of days * 8 as hours should work.
For example, supposing someone spent one full day and 3 hours the next day working on something, this person could use '11h' when logging time.
fields.summary: Smart commit #time does not log work when days are used

h3. Summary
Migrating FishEye Database from MS SQL 2008 results in:

...

..
Restore failed. This may leave your target FISHEYE_INST directory  in an inconsistent state.

h3. Environment
MS SQL 2008
Any FishEye version

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 *Migrating from the FishEye Web UI*
# Go to {{Administration > Database}}
# Fill details for target Database
# Save and Migrate

*Command Line*
# Create back for your existing MS SQL 2008 database
# Run the following command:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
fisheyectl.sh restore --sql --file /path/to/backup.zip --dbtype <database type> --jdbcurl jdbc:<database-type-jdbc>://<hostname>:<port>/<database> --username <user name> --password <password> --force 
{code}

Migration should complete successfully

Restore failed. This may leave your target FISHEYE_INST directory  in an inconsistent state.
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
This is due to an incompatibility in date an timestamp format. Reason is sqlserver timestamp is saved as string, rather than a timestamp and FE is not able to restore that to New Target Database

{{cwd_user.created_date}} and {{cwd_user.updated_date}} have the following formats in {{sql/database.xml}}:

|| DB || date example ||
| H2 | {{<timestamp>2017-01-31T12:08:56.207Z</timestamp>}} |
| postgres | {{<timestamp>2017-01-31T12:08:56.207Z</timestamp>}} |
| mysql | {{<timestamp>2017-01-31T14:07:45.000Z</timestamp>}} |
| sql server 2008 | {{<escapedString>2017-01-31 12:33:06.2070000</escapedString>}} |

h3.Workaround

Manually correct the sql/database.xml file

{noformat}$ unzip backup.zip sql/database.xml
$ sed -E 's|<escapedString>([0-9]{4}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{2}) ([0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}\.[0-9]{3})0000</escapedString>|<timestamp>\1T\2Z</timestamp>|g' sql/database.xml > sql/database2.xml
$ mv sql/database2.xml sql/database.xml
$ zip -u backup.zip sql/database.xml{noformat}

    return callcatch(ui, _runcatchfunc)
  File "/opt/bamboo-agent/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/FECRU-HGMATRIX-FECRUHGMATRIX29/output/hg-bin/mercurial-4.1-rc/fecru/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mercurial/dispatch.py", line 227, in callcatch

  File "/opt/bamboo-agent/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/FECRU-HGMATRIX-FECRUHGMATRIX29/output/hg-bin/mercurial-4.1-rc/fecru/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mercurial/scmutil.py", line 152, in callcatch

fields.description:
h3. Summary

FishEye renders binary file in SVN repository as text when the filename contains *round brackets '(', ')'* and FishEye uses *native SVN* for the indexing. (This problem didn't happen when using *SVNKit*.)
This is different problem from the one which is mentioned in [this KB|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/fisheye-renders-binary-file-in-svn-repository-as-text-792498092.html]. Even if {{svn:mime-type}} of the file is set to {{application/octet-stream}}, this problem could be reproduced.
h3. Environment
 * Ubuntu 16.04
 * SVN 1.9.3

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a SVN repository
 # Add any file to the repository and commit it (revision 1)
 (i) This step is important. I couldn't reproduce this problem in case that I added the problematic file in the initial commit. You should commit the problematic file *after the initial commit*.
 # Add a binary file named "(test).pptx" to the repository and commit it (revision 2)
 # Make change in the binary file and commit it (revision 3)
 # Configure FishEye to use native SVN
 # Add the repository to FishEye
 # Execute full re-indexing to the repository
 # Check the diff between revision 2 and revision 3 on the UI

h3. Expected Results

"(test).pptx" should be handled as binary.
h3. Actual Results

"(test).pptx" was handled as text.
h3. Notes

As I mentioned above, in case that we added the problematic file to the repository in the *initial commit*, this problem couldn't be reproduced.
In order to reproduce this problem, we have to add the file to the repository *after the initial commit*.

When I reproduce this problem on my local, the following SVN commands seemed to be executed while re-indexing.
{code:java}
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn cat -r 3 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test/%28test%29.pptx@3 took 3 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn info -r HEAD http://vagrant.vm/svn/test/@HEAD took 4 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn info -R -r 2 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test/%28test%29.pptx@2 took 5 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn proplist -r 1 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test/test.pptx@1 took 6 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn diff --summarize -r 2:3 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test/@3 took 7 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn info -R -r 1 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test@1 took 8 millis
2017-01-20 00:49:25,855 DEBUG [InitPing1 test_native ] fisheye IndexingStats-dump - svn diff -r 2:3 http://vagrant.vm/svn/test@3 took 10 millis
{code}
h3. Workaround

Please use SVNKit instead.
fields.summary: FishEye renders binary file in SVN repository as text when using native SVN

fields.description:
With the Crowd server existing in a different domain, Confluence and JIRA are able to overwrite the Crowd {{cookie.domain}} but post 4.0, FishEye/Crucible is not.

Previously, users could specify the {{cookie.domain}} in the FeCru {{config.xml}}.
h5. Scenario

||Application||Domain||Crowd Domain||Overwrite Domain||Results||
|Crowd|.foo.com|N/A|N/A|N/A|
|JIRA|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Works|
|Confluence|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Works|
|FeCru|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Unable to overwrite|
h5. Request

Allow FeCru to overwrite the Crowd cookie.domain setting like JIRA and Confluence are able to do.
fields.summary: Would like to overwrite the Crowd SSO domain configuration

fields.description:
*Symptoms:*

Scanning P4 repository by FishEye using a command:
{noformat}
DEBUG [InitPing2 AlertCentral ] fisheye P4CliUtils-dumpCommandLine - [localhost:1666//depot] Executing C:\Perforce\p4.exe -p localhost:1666 -u readonly -ztag -x - changes -l 
{noformat}
stops with the following error in a stack trace:
{noformat}
DEBUG [InitPing2 AlertCentral ] fisheye P4Exec-getProcessStatusMessage - Exception processing P4 command - returning as status
com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "SOME TEXT"
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl.handleHandlerError(ExternalProcessImpl.java:273) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl.access$300(ExternalProcessImpl.java:18) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl$3.doTask(ExternalProcessImpl.java:317) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.LatchedRunnable.run(LatchedRunnable.java:36) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142) [?:1.8.0_102]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617) [?:1.8.0_102]
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) [?:1.8.0_102]
Caused by: java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "SOME TEXT"
	at java.lang.NumberFormatException.forInputString(NumberFormatException.java:65) [?:1.8.0_102]
	at java.lang.Long.parseLong(Long.java:589) [?:1.8.0_102]
	at java.lang.Long.parseLong(Long.java:631) [?:1.8.0_102]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.perforce.client.P4Client$3.processGroup(P4Client.java:137) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.perforce.client.P4ZTagExtractor.processLine(P4ZTagExtractor.java:43) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.perforce.client.P4OutputLineProcessor.processOutput(P4OutputLineProcessor.java:34) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.perforce.client.P4Exec$3.process(P4Exec.java:193) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.PluggableProcessHandler.processOutput(PluggableProcessHandler.java:127) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.util.NamedProcessHandler.processOutput(NamedProcessHandler.java:31) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl$3.doTask(ExternalProcessImpl.java:315) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
	... 4 more{noformat}
This can happen when a commit contains a multi-line comment and the next line of comment starts with: {{"... change"}} string. Example:
{noformat}
... change 785823
... time 1480677702
... user alice
... client ALICE
... status submitted
... changeType public
... path //depot/Src/...
... oldChange 785815
... desc first line of description
... change second line of description
{noformat}
 

*Cause:*

This is because FishEye scanner recognises "... change second line of description" from the description field as a start of new commit block from the log.

 

*Workaround:*

Edit existing commit comment and remove "... change" from the beginning of the line (e.g. remove dots or make it single-line):
 p4 change -f <change number>
 Note: this requires superuser permissions in Perforce.

 

*Expected bug fix:*

Recognise multi-line comment description.
fields.summary: NumberFormatException when scanning Perforce repository
